results.headline: A Death in Paraguay Leads a Niece to Brutal Truths

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 108

results.summary_short: In “108 (Cuchillo de Palo)” Renate Costa investigates the secret life of her gay uncle, who had mysteriously amassed a fortune in Paraguay.

results.headline: Life-Altering Plea for Help

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Call

results.summary_short: In “The Call,” a 911 operator takes a life-altering call from a teenage girl who has just been abducted.

results.headline: Debauchery and the American Experience (Woo-Hoo!)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spring Breakers

results.summary_short: “Spring Breakers” delves into a deeply American topic: the pursuit of happiness taken to nihilistic extremes.

results.headline: Onstage All of His Life, but Aching to Be Seen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reality

results.summary_short: “Reality,” a film by Matteo Garrone, follows a fishmonger as he attempts to land a place on Italy’s version of “Big Brother.”

results.headline: A Rapper in Search of a New Path

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reincarnated

results.summary_short: In “Reincarnated” the rapper Snoop Dogg, who now wants to be known as Snoop Lion, heads to Jamaica for a spiritual pilgrimage of sorts.

results.headline: Lustful Pursuit of Sensory Overload

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vanishing Waves

results.summary_short: “Vanishing Waves,” a psychedelic science-fiction tale, is a discomfiting blend of visual ecstasy and narrative sterility.

results.headline: Suspending More Than Disbelief

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Upside Down

results.summary_short: Kirsten Dunst and Jim Sturgess are lovers kept apart by physics, among other forces, in a new release with a science-fiction twist.

results.headline: A Troubled Veteran Meets a New Enemy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kill Hole

results.summary_short: In “The Kill Hole” a brooding veteran who was involved in an atrocity while fighting overseas gets no respite back home.

results.headline: Sleepwalking Magician Pulls a New Self Out of a Hat

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Incredible Burt Wonderstone

results.summary_short: In “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone,” Steve Carell is a successful Las Vegas magician who faces a challenge from a take-no-prisoners newcomer played by Jim Carrey.

results.headline: Things That Go Bump in the Night, Still

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Amityville Horror

results.summary_short: “My Amityville Horror” focuses on Daniel Lutz, who was a child in the family at the center of the 1979 movie “The Amityville Horror.”

results.headline: Not in Kansas Anymore: Following a Dream to Mexico

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mariachi Gringo

results.summary_short: In “Mariachi Gringo” a confused blond and blue-eyed Kansan escapes to Mexico to play mariachi, puzzling out his life in a foreign land that feels vibrant and authentic.

results.headline: Prison Jumpsuits Are So Passé

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of K-11

results.summary_short: In “K-11” a stoned record producer is dumped into a jail’s holding pen for gay and transgendered inmates, and the lacy underwear and hooker heels do not make him a happy man.

results.headline: Fast Friends, With Man in Middle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of If I Were You

results.summary_short: “If I Were You” is the story of a boozy middle-aged marketing executive who impulsively bonds with her husband’s girlfriend.

results.headline: Ticking Bomb in Their Friendship

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ginger and Rosa

results.summary_short: In “Ginger & Rosa,” a coming-of-age story directed by Sally Potter, the close friendship of two teenagers comes undone with an act of treachery.

results.headline: Everyday Life, Washed in the Colors of Memory

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From up on Poppy Hill

results.summary_short: “From Up on Poppy Hill” was written by Hayao Miyazaki, the renowned Japanese animator, and directed by his son Goro.

results.headline: Jamaican Passions in a Time of Tumult

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Better Mus' Come

results.summary_short: “Better Mus’ Come” is a love story set in the political turmoil and gang warfare in 1970s Jamaica.

results.headline: Looking Past the Alter Egos to the Novelist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Philip Roth Unmasked

results.summary_short: It’s fitting that Mr. Roth dominates the screen in the new documentary “Philip Roth: Unmasked,” given that his great subject has always been himself.

results.headline: A Mother-Son Dance With Many Awkward Steps

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Killed My Mother

results.summary_short: The plot of “I Killed My Mother” centers on the difficult relationship between a teenager and his parent.

results.headline: Last Stop, Adulthood, the Bronx

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The We and the I

results.summary_short: Michel Gondry’s film “The We and the I” captures the chaos, glee and heartache of the last day of school for a group of boisterous South Bronx high school students.

results.headline: The Power of Faith, for Good and Ill

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond the Hills

results.summary_short: In “Beyond the Hills,” by the Romanian director Cristian Mungiu, a girl who visits her friend at an isolated rural convent is suspected of being possessed.
